'''''A Nervous Smile''''' is a play written by [[John Belluso]] that was originally commissioned by the [[Actors Theatre of Louisville]]. It opened March 4, 2005 for the 29th annual [[Humana Festival of New American Plays]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Belluso|first1=John|title=A Nervous Smile|date=2006|publisher=Dramatists Play Services Inc.|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-8222-2095-4}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://actorstheatre.org/humana-festival-of-new-american-plays/|title=Humana Festival of New American Plays - Actors Theatre of Louisville|website=Actors Theatre of Louisville|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-13}}</ref> The play was originally directed by [[David Esbjornson]] and starred Sean Haberle as Brian, Maureen Mueller as Eileen, Mhari Sandoval as Nic, and [[Dale Soules]] as Blanka. Unseen characters include heavy reference to Brian and Eileen's child Emily and Nic's son Dominic, both of whom have severe [[cerebral palsy]] as well as to Nic's ex-husband and Blanka's adult daughter. The story is set in a present-day Manhattan apartment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anervoussmile.wordpress.com/the-play/|title=The Play|website=A Nervous Smile|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}}</ref>
== Characters ==
'''Brian:''' Husband to Eileen in his late 30s, a college professor and failed novelist. Throughout the play he struggles to understand his place as father to a child with cerebral palsy and also grapples with his relationship to his wife and to the woman he is having an affair with.
'''Eileen:''' Wife to Brian in her early 40s. A multi-millionaire from investing in her father's company, she is snobbish, alcoholic, and regularly pops pills ([[Vicodine]] and [[Oxycontin]] being the two primarily mentioned and utilized drugs). She doesn't have any desire to be raising a child with cerebral palsy but also feels a motherly instinct to remain with Emily that Brian doesn't appear to feel.
'''Nic:''' A single mom who was once good friends with Eileen. She is now having an affair with Brian. She works as a lawyer who can hardly support her son Dominic, who has severe cerebral palsy. She initially agrees to run away with Brian but freezes up at the last moment and decides she must stay with her son.
'''Blanka:''' Brian and Eileen's maid in her late 50s. She is originally from Russia and is the one who actually cares for Emily. Blanka knows Emily's secrets and is the only character in this play to acknowledge Emily as a real person.
== Plot ==
=== Act I === The play begins with Brian, Eileen, and Nic returning to Brian and Eileen's apartment in Manhattan. They've just come from the funeral of a child from the Cerebral Palsy Support Group that the three attend. They stopped at a bar on their way home and seem to show an overall lack of empathy for the family of the child that passed. There are clear tensions among the three and while Eileen is out of the room it is revealed that Brian is having an affair with Nic. You then find out that offstage Emily is having a seizure and Eileen once again exits to calm her daughter. While she is away Brian admits his and Eileen's plan. He tells Nic of his dreams to live with her in Buenos Aires and this can happen because Eileen is going to grant him a divorce as well as half of his money ($10 million) and a promise that they will never see one another again. The couple have planned to abandon Emily at the emergency room in the middle of the night. Brian wants Nic to come with him and insists that she call Dominic's father to have him pick up their son so Nic can run away with Brian. The act ends with Eileen returning to the living room and encouraging Nic to go with the plan and to love Brian. Just before the blackout, Nic agrees to go.
=== Act II === This act opens during the middle of the next night, the night in which they plan on abandoning their children and running away. Nic arrives at the apartment early feeling overwhelmed and needing to begin the plan immediately. Brian agrees and goes to wake Eileen and gather her things. While he does so, Nic is left alone. Suddenly, Blanka wakes from where she is sleeping under a blanket on the living room couch. She speaks with Nic and tries to understand why Nic feels the need to abandon her child and Blanka works desperately to convince Nic to stay. Nic, in response, tells her of one of the 'bad days' Dominic had recently and how overwhelmed she has become caring for him, reasoning that because of this her only option is to leave. The scene ends with Brian carrying a sleeping Emily out the door with Nic and Eileen close on his heels.
=== Act III === This act begins once more in the Manhattan apartment. Nic and Eileen sit in the living room. The audience learns that Brian left Nic at the airport security check when she began to have second thoughts about running away with him and abandoning her son. It is also revealed that Eileen had fallen into a drug-induced sleep at her own gate and missed her flight to London. Police found them both and they were quickly arrested for child abandonment. Nic has luckily been granted shared custody of her son. However, Eileen is likely to lose Emily and is having to pack up her things which will be picked up by social workers as Emily is going into foster care. As the two women reflect on their shared experiences the image of Brian (wherever he is in the world) appears and he expresses his true hatred for Emily and everything she represents to him. Blanka then returns, having spent all of the money that Brian originally paid her to not go to the police. In an emotional outburst, she convinces Eileen to listen to some of Emily's poems which is the last thing the audience hears as the lights go out. They hear a robotic communication board voice slowly becoming the voice of a little girl.
== Past productions == * Produced by the New Theatre at The Roxy Performing Arts Center in [[Florida]] and directed by Rickey J. Martinez. * Presented by [[Theater Breaking Through Barriers|Theatre Breaking Through Barriers]] at the [[Kirk Theatre|Kirk Theater]] in [[New York, NY]] in 2009 and directed by Ike Schambelan. * Produced by Dramatic Repertory Company at Portland Stage Studio Theater in [[Maine]] in 2012 and directed by Whitney Smith.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://anervoussmile.wordpress.com/about/|title=Notable Productions|website=A Nervous Smile|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}}</ref>
== Augmented communication == In some cases of cerebral palsy, the damage is so severe that is affects the person's speech and language abilities. While they may be able to have complex thoughts and ideas, their muscles and vocal chords are unable to form the words that they are trying to express. Augmented forms of communication can vary greatly and include non-technology picture boards,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amyspeechlanguagetherapy.com/communication-boards.html|title=Communication Boards|website=Amy Speech & Language Therapy, Inc.|access-date=2016-04-14}}</ref> text boards and digitized speech.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ioddev.org/inventory_detail.php?equip_id=2657|title=Institute on Disabilities {{!}} Programs {{!}} Assistive Technology {{!}} PATLL {{!}}ECO2 Communication Device|website=www.ioddev.org|access-date=2016-04-14}}</ref> In ''A Nervous Smile,'' we see the two different ends of the augmented communication spectrum, with Dominic possessing a basic communication board and Emily having both an advanced wheelchair and advanced augmented communication that can provide a voice, save things she's said, and predict what she will say.
== See also == * [[The Cripple of Inishmaan]] * [[Sunrise at Campobello (play)]] * [[Whose Life Is It Anyway? (play)]] * [[The Glass Menagerie]]

In [[painting]], a '''retarder''' is a substance, usually added to [[water]], used to slow the drying time of [[acrylic paints]], giving more time for [[Mixing (process engineering)|blending]] or [[layering]] [[Specular highlight|highlights]].
==Use in fine art== Retarders are used to counter the fast drying properties of acrylic paints making possible the usage of wet on wet or other techniques which would otherwise require oil paints. Even if they will never give acrylic the working time oil paints permits, depending how much it is adding to paint, they can give anywhere from half an hour to a full day's working time.
==Content== They generally contain glycol (such as [[propylene glycol]]) or glycerin-based additives.
== Home-Made == For home-made acrylic retarder, water [[glycerol]] down about 5:1 (water: glycerol) and apply to paint.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paintingclinic.com/clinic/guestarticles/retarder.htm |title=Home Made Acrylic Retarders |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515215304/http://www.paintingclinic.com/clinic/guestarticles/retarder.htm |archive-date=15 May 2013 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> Non-toxic car anti-freeze, which contains propylene glycol can also be used.
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Aesthetic judgement''', often also referred to as ‘taste’, is a concept in [[aesthetics]] which attempts to explain the nature of judgements of [[beauty]] and whether or not these judgements are legitimate.
The key idea for most traditional theories of taste was that objects possessed concrete properties that the perceiver ought to judge as beautiful or not. Failure to make the correct judgement was considered as something deficient within the beholder, whether that be a flaw within the person’s virtue or connected to a lack of knowledge that hinders their ability to perceive the beauty of the object.
Aesthetic judgement as a concept rose to prominence in the eighteenth century, however its roots can be traced back many years to ancient Greek and medieval philosophers.
== Ancient conceptions of aesthetic judgement == [[File:Sanzio 01 Plato Aristotle.jpg|thumb|The central image from Raphael's ''[[The School of Athens]]'' (1509-1511), depicting Plato (left) and Aristotle (right). Plato is depicted pointing upwards, in reference to his theory of forms, whilst Aristotle disagrees and points down towards reality, in reference to his belief in [[empiricism]].]] [[Ancient Greek philosophy|Ancient Greek philosophers]] did not possess an explicit concept of aesthetic judgement, however their ideas regarding aesthetics inspired later developments.
=== Plato === [[Plato|Plato’s]] [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] theory held that there is an incorporeal realm in which the perfect [[Theory of forms|Forms]] of reality exist. This includes the perfect Form of Beauty, which one can rise up to through a [[Dialectic|dialectical]] method. Thus, in Plato’s terms, knowledge is critical to developing a better understanding of beauty and thus, a better capacity for aesthetic judgement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/a-taste/|title=Aesthetic Taste|last=Spicher|first=Michael|date=|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Aristotle === [[Aristotle]] purported a more [[Experiential knowledge|experiential]] approach to aesthetic judgement, in that beauty was a property of objects being related to their size and proportion. To develop a capacity for aesthetic judgement, one has to observe enough objects of the same kind to uncover the correct form of those things. Both Aristotle and Plato perceived beauty as a property existing outside of human experience, with aesthetic judgement being the capacity to recognise that beauty, developed by the search for beauty in things.<ref name=":0" />
== Medieval conceptions of aesthetic judgement == Although Medieval philosophers did not possess a particular notion of individual preference or taste, they were particularly preoccupied with a [[Cosmology|cosmological]] interpretation of beauty, with relation to specific [[Ontology|ontological]] properties. This is attributed to the fact that philosophers of the medieval age had an object notion of beauty, and also because it was a common belief that morality was linked with beauty.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marinescu|first=Axia|date=2014-01-01|title=Beauty and Judgement in German Aesthetics|url=https://content.sciendo.com/view/journals/hssr/3/1/article-p124.xml|journal=Human & Social Studies. Research and Practice|language=en|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.2478/hssr-2013-0024|issn=2285-5920}}</ref>
=== Augustine of Hippo === Expanding upon Plato’s Theory of the Forms, [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] believed that perfect beauty existed within God. Augustine proposed equality and unity as the two properties that made physical objects beautiful. Aesthetic judgement is thus the ability of an individual to recognise the unity and equality of an object, thus involving an exercise of reason and knowledge, similar to the theories of previous thinkers.<ref name=":0" /> Since the ultimate state of beauty exists in God’s mind, an observer can only recognise this through [[divine illumination]]. Thus, one’s capacity for aesthetic judgement is improved the closer one is to God.
=== Thomas Aquinas === [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]] also presented properties that make an object beautiful: proportion, wholeness and radiance. Thus, similar to his philosophical predecessors, he constituted the judgement of beauty to be dependent on knowledge and occurring through the function of cognition. Possessing a capacity for aesthetic judgement is therefore determined by one’s ability to recognise these properties in observed objects. Aquinas does however diverge from previous philosophers on certain notions. His definition of that beauty as "that which, when seen, pleases" can be interpreted as an implication of the subjectivity of beauty and thus judgements about it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wood|first=Robert E.|date=2015-06-23|title=Review of Aquinas on Beauty|url=https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/aquinas-on-beauty/|issn=1538-1617}}</ref> Furthermore, he rejects Plato’s Theory of Forms, stating that beauty is a real quality present within objects. Ultimately however he converges upon Augustine’s view that God is the source of all beauty.<ref name=":0" />
== 18th century theories of aesthetic judgement == Explicit theories of aesthetic judgement emerged and predominated in the 18<sup>th</sup> century, being referred to as “the century of taste”.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/435824318|title=The century of taste : the philosophical odyssey of taste in the eighteenth century|last=1926-|first=Dickie, George,|date=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195357134|location=New York|oclc=435824318}}</ref> Philosophers developed a more introspective stance to attempt to understand their personal dispositions to beauty.
=== Anthony Cooper, the Third Earl of Shaftesbury === [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury|Anthony Cooper]] (1671-1713), the Third Earl of Shaftesbury, purported his philosophical ideas through his [[Socratic dialogue]] “The Moralists, a Philosophical Rhapsody”, which stands in almost direct contrast to the theories and assumptions posited by Addison.<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=Shelley|first=James|title=18th Century British Aesthetics|date=2018|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2018/entries/aesthetics-18th-british/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2018|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Shaftesbury claimed that taste was a quality innate within human beings. One’s capacity to observe and make correct judgements of beauty was dependent on one’s moral righteousness. The key property Shaftesbury ascribed to beautiful objects is harmony, the prime source of which is nature, which in turn is formed by God who is constituted as the ultimate source of beauty.
=== Joseph Addison === [[Joseph Addison]] (1672-1719) posited theories that were in almost direct contrast to those of Shaftesbury. Central to Addison’s theory of aesthetic judgement is the concept that pleasures of taste are essentially “pleasures of the imagination”.<ref name=":1" /> Addison’s fundamental divergence from Shaftesbury is that he views taste to be a judgement of visual representation as exercised by the imagination, rather than as an exercise of the intellect and of moral righteousness. Addison constituted two types of pleasures of the imagination: primary pleasures, as in those derived from visual images directly observed by an individual of an object in front of them and secondary pleasures, which arise from images of objects that are absent from sight and therefore exist only in the mind. Addison’s materialist basis predisposes his theory to subjectivism and relativism, leading Addison to declare that there “is not perhaps any real beauty”.<ref name=":1" />
=== Alexander Gerard === [[Alexander Gerard]] (1728-1795) considered taste in a similar fashion to the six external [[Sense|senses]], in that experiences of aesthetic judgement are also simple and instantaneous. He also developed his views from the philosophical framework of [[associationism]]. Aesthetic judgements are exercises of the faculty of imagination, in which a newly observed object is associated to previous ideas in the mind of the observer.<ref name=":0" /> Gerard determines that taste is improved when a person exercises their capacities for judgment and taste to recognise the four core elements of sensibility, refinement, correctness and proportion within objects.
== David Hume's theory of taste == David Hume’s theories on aesthetic judgement were purported in his 1757 essay ''[[Four Dissertations|Of the Standard of Taste]]''. Hume ascribed some normative quality to aesthetic judgements whilst providing critiques of the more relativist positions on the matter. Whilst acknowledging that judgements cannot reasonably be determined to be objectively true or false, he championed the notion of “common sense”, which held that some evaluations are better than others.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://web.mnstate.edu/gracyk/courses/phil%20of%20art/hume_and_kant.htm|title=Aesthetic theories of David Hume and Immanuel Kant|website=web.mnstate.edu|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Hume also reinforced the conception of aesthetic judgements as an exercise of the faculty of the imagination, determining beauty to not be a property of objects but existing only in the mind, and the ones that are deemed more beautiful are the ones that affect the higher sentiments, or high cognitive or intellectual capacities of the observer. Hume also sought to establish a universal standard of aesthetic judgement, seeking a basis upon which we can “confirm” one sentiment and “condemn” another.<ref name=":2" /> In doing this he refers to [[Classic book|classic texts]] which seemingly have received universal acclaim beyond through different times and cultures. Hume asserts that such universal acclamation identifies a work of real genius, and such works should be examined to provide us with guidelines for the composition of good art. Hume provides characteristics of what he refers to as a true judge in matters of aesthetics: [[File:Painting of David Hume.jpg|thumb|''Portrait of David Hume'' ''(1711-1776)'']] {{Quote|text="Strong sense, united to delicate sentiment, improved by practice, perfected by comparison, and cleared of all prejudice”|sign=David Hume|source="Four Dissertations", Of the Standard of Taste}}The consensus of these critics constitutes what Hume called a “joint verdict”<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/aesthetic-judgment|title=Aesthetic Judgment {{!}} Encyclopedia.com|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>, which composes the "true standard"<ref name=":2" /> for aesthetic judgements. This standard is constituted as universally correct, and failure to recognise pleasure in the object is considered a defect within the observer.
Hume does concede however that certain subjectivities affecting aesthetic judgements cannot be eliminated. He indicates two circumstances that will create irrevocable prejudices. First he refers to natural, generational and cultural dispositions which are fundamental and relative to individuals. The second is determined by the critics’ degree of moral righteousness. Ascribing a normative characteristic to morality, Hume declares that aesthetic merit is influenced by “the natural boundaries of vice and virtue”<ref name=":2" />, and if the artist does not conform to these moral regulations then they and their art will inevitably divert from Hume’s true standard.
== Immanuel Kant's "judgement of taste" == Central to the concept of aesthetic judgement is Kant’s notion of the “judgement of taste”, introduced in his seminal 1790 book the ''[[Critique of Judgment|Critique of Judgement]].'' In the text, Kant determined two essential conditions for a judgement to be classified as a judgement of taste – subjectivity and universality.
Subjectivity refers to the fact that a judgement of taste is based on a feeling of pleasure or displeasure. The second necessary condition of a judgement of taste is that it claims “universal validity”, which Kant describes as follows:
{{Quote|text=“… when [a man] puts a thing on a pedestal and calls it beautiful, he demands the same delight from others. He judges not merely from himself, but for all men, and then speaks of beauty as if it were a property of things”|sign=Immanuel Kant|source=Critique of Judgement}} Kant emphasises the fact that requiring the agreement of others is an inextricable characteristic of aesthetic judgements. We think that others “ought” to share our judgement, and we blame them if they don’t, as if there was a deficiency within them to recognise beauty and make judgements upon it.<ref>{{Citation|last=Zangwill|first=Nick|title=Aesthetic Judgment|date=2014|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2014/entries/aesthetic-judgment/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2014|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Aesthetic judgements, unique from other types of judgements that Kant lists, therefore make a claim to universal validity. Kant also states that pleasure in beauty is disinterested in that it is desire-free. Whilst agreeing that pleasure in beauty can generate desire, he states that it is an essential characteristic of aesthetic judgements that they are found to be pleasurable because they are judged to be beautiful, rather than being judged as beautiful because they are found to be pleasurable.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/kantaest/#SH2a|title=Immanuel Kant: Aesthetics|last=Burnham|first=Douglas|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
Kant provides a “deep” account of the nature of pleasure in beauty, which states that it accomplished through the simultaneous exercise of the cognitive faculties of imagination and understanding.<ref name=":4" /> This is the premise upon which Kant asserts his normative claim on aesthetic judgements. Because these judgements are a function of cognitive faculties, which Kant assumed can be shared by humans, it must be possible for them to be shared. Kant also purported that pleasure in beauty can be attributed to our recognition that the qualities of an object conform to basic functions of human cognition. We maintain a presupposition that all objects seemed to be formed in a way that enables them to be analysed by human observers. Beauty is the quality of an object assuming a “form of purposiveness”, despite the absence of an identification of a specific purpose.<ref name=":2" /> When we respond to an object’s appearance without any comprehension of utility, we respond in an aesthetic manner. The feeling of pleasure is a signal that the object is able to be comprehended through exercising the human faculty of understanding. An aesthetic judgement is therefore a judgement about human cognition rather than a material object.
== Nineteenth and twentieth century theories of aesthetic judgement == Philosophical concerns with aesthetic judgement declined rapidly after the 19<sup>th</sup> century, with the majority of discourse shifting to the concept of an aesthetic attitude.<ref name=":0" /> Despite this, there have been philosophers who have persisted with the concept of aesthetic taste, which has resulted in some notable contributions in contemporary times.
=== Frank Sibley === [[Frank Sibley (philosopher)|Frank Sibley]] (1929-1996) defined aesthetic judgements to be evaluations that apply aesthetic concepts to objects through aesthetic terminology. Taste is thus an individual’s capacity to recognise these properties and employ aesthetic concepts and terms appropriately to describe them.<ref name=":3" /> Sibley also asserts that aesthetic judgements are objective and that beauty is an objective property present within objects, departing from the 18<sup>th</sup> century philosophical norm of subjectivist interpretation.
== References ==

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Azlan McLennan | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1975}} | birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | known_for = [[Visual art]] | education = [[Victorian College of the Arts]] in [[Melbourne]]. | movement = [[Anti-art]], [[Political satire]] | notable_works = | patrons = | influenced by = [[Marxism]] | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Azlan McLennan''' (born 1975 in the United States)<ref name="Art labels">[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,18507141-2702,00.html "Art labels Howard a terrorist"] ''The Australian,'' 18 March 2006. Accessed 1 May 2008</ref> is a visual artist and socialist activist based in [[Melbourne]], Australia.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1984&Itemid=106 "Trotsky vs Stalin: Azlan McLennan"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 141, May 2009. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> He is a graduate of the [[Victorian College of the Arts]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110728000321/http://savevca.org/vca/alumni "Alumni of the V.C.A."] ''Save the VCA''. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> His art is known for its political content and has been the subject of considerable debate and media attention in Australia.<ref>[http://www.visualarts.net.au/files/NAVAQuarterly(segment).pdf "Artist Profile: Azlan McLennan"] ''NAVA Quarterly''. December 2005. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref>
== Art == [[File:Proudly UnAustralian.jpg|thumb|250px|right|''Proudly UnAustralian'' by Azlan McLennan, confiscated by the Victoria Police in Melbourne, 2006.]] Conceptually, McLennan's work tends to be unambiguous and antagonistic from a left-wing perspective, loosely following the traditions of [[agitprop]], [[anti-art]] and [[Institutional Critique]], incorporating elements of [[détournement]], [[readymade]] or [[installation art|installation]]. His works have often been characterised as controversial by conservative politicians, journalists and art critics, usually portraying the artist in a negative light.<ref name="The politics">[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/05/13/1084289821310.html "The politics of art"] ''The Age,'' 14 May 2004. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> Alternatively, various liberal lawyers, academics and activists have defended his works, usually on the basis of [[free speech]], due to the offence sometimes caused by his art for its often overt left-leaning bias.<ref>[http://www.visualarts.net.au/files/NQ%20Dec%2008_fin.pdf "25 Years: NAVA at the forefront of Australia’s cultural policy agenda"] ''NAVA Quarterly''. December 2008. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> The artist has expressed public criticisms over [[Zionism]], the [[War on Terror]], [[Australian nationalism]] and racism, the [[Mandatory detention in Australia|mandatory detention]] of [[asylum seekers]], various political figures and the [[managerial class]] of the [[art world]].<ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:WhLNCpl6XgEJ:www.visualarts.net.au/files/Art_Censorship.pdf "Dealing With Art Censorship"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''National Association for the Visual Arts'' Media Release, 30 March 2009. Accessed 20 April 2009</ref>
McLennan has cited the artists [[John Heartfield]]<ref name="Azlan">[http://artabase.net/artist/820-azlan-mclennan Azlan McLennan] ''Artabase''. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> and [[Leon Kuhn]]<ref name="left">[http://redflag.org.au/article/left-loses-inspiring-artist-and-comrade The Left loses an inspiring artist and comrade] ''Red Flag'', 31 December 2013. Accessed 3 January 2014</ref> as influences. He has work in collections of the [[National Gallery of Australia]]<ref name="Azlan" /> and the [[National Library of Australia]].<ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/5057674 "Be young & shut up"] ''National Library of Australia''. Accessed 4 November 2013</ref>
== Political affiliations == McLennan is a member of the [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] organisation [[Socialist Alternative (Australia)|Socialist Alternative]].<ref name="Connex">[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=5976:connex-tries-to-censor-pro-palestinian-art "Connex tries to censor pro-Palestinian art"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' 11 March 2009. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> Previously, he has been associated with the [[Socialist Alliance (Australia)|Socialist Alliance]],<ref>[http://www.melbourne-palestine.info/resources/ageunholyalliance.htm "Zionism and imperialism: an unholy alliance"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010095232/http://www.melbourne-palestine.info/resources/ageunholyalliance.htm |date=10 October 2007 }} ''Melbourne Palestine Solidarity Network,'' 9 August 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> the [[Stop the War Coalition (Australia)|Stop the War Coalition]],<ref>[http://azlanmclennan.com/?page_id=312 "Propaganda"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314052529/http://azlanmclennan.com/?page_id=312 |date=14 March 2009 }} ''Azlan McLennan'' website. Accessed 25 January 2009</ref> [[Students for Palestine]],<ref>[https://archive.is/20130415225029/http://www.studentsforpalestine.org/?p=314 "Artists Support Boycott Israel 19"] ''Students for Palestine,'' 18 August 2011. Accessed 24 April 2012</ref> the [[Refugee Action Collective (Victoria)|Refugee Action Collective]],<ref>[http://redpenzine.wordpress.com/ The Red Pen Zine] ''The Red Pen''. Accessed 16 November 2010</ref> the [[University of Melbourne Graduate Student Association]],<ref>[http://www.gsa.unimelb.edu.au/elections/Annual_Graduate_Student_Elections_2009.shtml "Annual Graduate Student Elections 2009"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223053959/http://www.gsa.unimelb.edu.au/elections/Annual_Graduate_Student_Elections_2009.shtml |date=23 February 2010 }} ''University of Melbourne Graduate Student Association,'' 15 August. 2009. Accessed 27 January 2010</ref> the [[Victorian College of the Arts Student Union]]<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/component/content/article/194-edition-145/2086-vca-students-fight-job-and-course-cuts VCA students fight job and course cuts]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 145, September 2009. Accessed 12 June 2010</ref> and the [[United Voice]] trade union.<ref>[http://menasolidaritynetwork.com/2011/05/30/egypt-hossam-el-hamalawy-and-reem-maged-called-before-military-judges/ Egypt: Hossam el-Hamalawy and Reem Maged called before military judges] ''MENA Solidarity Network,'' 30 May 2011. Accessed 7 January 2014</ref> He regularly produces posters for the Australian [[Far-left politics|far left's]] various political demonstrations and meetings.<ref name="Azlan" /> He has written articles for the publications of both Socialist Alternative and the Socialist Alliance.<ref name="left" /><ref name="Connex" />
== Controversy ==
=== Victorian College of the Arts === In August 2003, McLennan hired a [[G4S|Group 4 Securicor]] guard to keep gallery punters out of an exhibition opening at the VCA. Group 4 run [[immigration detention]] centres in Australia, such as [[Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre|Baxter Detention Centre]] and the now closed [[Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre|Woomera Detention Centre]]. The security guard was reportedly humiliated due to the incident which occurred at a time of high criticism of the [[John Howard]] government's treatment of [[Refugee#Asylum seekers|asylum seekers]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20121209182233/http://www.theage.com.au/cgi-bin/common/popupPrintArticle.pl?path=/articles/2003/09/03/1062548903857.html "VCA artwork raises ethics concerns"] ''The Age,'' 4 September 2003. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== 24seven === In May 2004, McLennan produced ''Fifty-six,'' an exhibition designed to coincide with [[Nakba Day]], the title drawing on the number of years since the establishment of [[Israel]]. The public exhibition in the shop front window space of 24seven Gallery on one of Melbourne CBD's busy streets, was censored by the [[City of Melbourne]] days after it was installed. The installation consisted of a large wall painting of an Israeli flag, with "debatable" statistics on the gallery's window about Israel's treatment of Palestinians. The scandal made international news, many pro-Israel individuals and groups accusing McLennan of [[antisemitism]]. This put a number of Victorian political figures such as former Premier [[Steve Bracks]], Lord Mayor [[John So]] and former City of Melbourne councillor Kimberly Kitching under pressure to respond. The use of taxpayer's money to fund the space fuelled a lot of the debate.<ref>[http://gallery.discoverymedia.com.au/artzinePub/story.asp?id=375&section=ExNews "Making Space – spanking the hand that feeds it"] ''Art Right Now,'' 16 June 2007. Accessed 22 May 2009</ref> McLennan also deeply outraged some critics by insinuating that the [[Nazis]] had a similar position on what they termed [[degenerate art]]. McLennan maintains a strong criticism of Israeli policies.<ref name="The politics" />
=== Citylights === In August 2004, McLennan displayed ''State Sponsored'', a collection of portraits of [[Hamas]] militants, including [[Sheikh Ahmed Yassin]] and [[Abdul Aziz Rantisi|Dr. Abdul Aziz Rantisi]] and the dates they were assassinated. The work was exhibited at Citylights project – a public art space in a Melbourne CBD lane way. McLennan was accused of glorifying terrorism by Ted Lapkin, a senior policy analyst of the [[Australia/Israel & Jewish Affairs Council]]. Andrew Mac, Citylights' curator and director defended the work on the grounds of diversity of opinion stating the artist's use of "state sponsored" referred to [[state terrorism]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Jewish-group-blasts-offensive-artwork/2004/12/10/1102625519852.html "Jewish group blasts 'offensive' artwork"] ''The Age,'' 10 December 2004. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Platform Artists Group === In September 2005, the City of Melbourne intervened to terminate McLennan's ''Canberra's 18'' exhibition shortly before it was scheduled to be shown at the [[Platform artists group]]'s [[Artist-run initiative]] (ARI), Platform 2. The exhibition was to include images of the then 18 Islamic organisations proscribed as terrorists by the Australian Government and the basis for their formation. City of Melbourne Deputy Mayor [[Gary Singer]] claimed the proper guidelines were not followed. Human rights campaigner and barrister [[Julian Burnside]] claimed the censorship was about governments testing how much Australians would tolerate such occurrences.<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/war-on-terrorism-is-claiming-victims-on-the-walls-of-art-galleries/2005/09/15/1126750082623.html "War on terrorism is claiming victims on the walls of art galleries"] ''Sydney Morning Herald,'' 16 September 2005. Accessed 3 May 2008</ref> McLennan accused City of Melbourne of political censorship and appeasing Zionists.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2005/09/14/1126377376345.html "City council bans 'terror artwork'"] ''The Age,'' 15 September 2005. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> Singer's areas of special interests ironically include [[civil liberties]].<ref>[http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=190&pa=1317&pg=1996 "Deputy Lord Mayor Gary Singer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725155111/http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=190&pa=1317&pg=1996 |date=25 July 2008 }} ''City of Melbourne,'' Accessed 3 May 2008</ref>
=== Monash University === [[Monash University Art and Design Faculty]] in Melbourne withdrew McLennan's video ''Mind the Gap'' in October 2005, ironically made for the same exhibition Monash had agreed to show the censored ''Canberra's 18'' work. The video contained graphic footage of the [[beheading]] of British contractor [[Kenneth Bigley]] by [[Jama'at al-Tawhid wal-Jihad|Tawhid and Jihad]] in 2004. The video criticised former British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] for his role in the Iraq war.<ref>[http://www.unmagazine.org/un7.html "Azlan McLennan"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080520005543/http://www.unmagazine.org/un7.html |date=20 May 2008 }} ''un Magazine,'' Volume 7, 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> The censorship is likely to have been motivated by the [[Australian Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005]], particularly the controversial return to the crime of [[sedition]] introduced by the Howard government some weeks later and passed into law the following month; a move highly unpopular amongst the arts sector.<ref>[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=71006 "Artists 'at risk' under terror laws"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627104653/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=71006 |date=27 June 2006 }} ''NineMSN,'' 8 November 2005. Accessed 29 April 2008</ref>
=== Urban Art === City of Melbourne and acting Transport Minister [[Bob Cameron (Victorian politician)|Bob Cameron]] censored ''Pay Your Way'' in January 2006 while McLennan was in residency in Indonesia. The posters – part of the Urbanart ARI program – were displayed in public tram shelters and pulled down only hours later due to complaints. The works featured images of [[Jean Charles de Menezes]], a Brazilian man shot dead by London police and accused Muslim terrorist, [[Joseph T. Thomas|Jack Thomas]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/fare-game-shelters-feel-the-brush-of-protest/2006/01/09/1136771500463.html "Fare game! Shelters feel the brush of protest"] ''The Age,'' 10 January 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> The works were characterised as racist and [[Islamophobic]],<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,17795788-2862,00.html "My art is not racist"] ''Herald Sun,'' 12 January 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> yet McLennan claimed the works were satirising the post [[9-11]] racism and Islamophobia perpetuated by pro-US governments. McLennan is also a [[Muslim]] himself.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=266&Itemid=106 "Political art meets a paranoid state"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 99, February 2006. Accessed 25 April 2008</ref> Thomas' lawyer, [[Rob Stary]] attacked the work for jeopardising the trial<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/public-art-threatens-fair-trial-thomas-lawyer/2006/01/11/1136956241052.html "Public art threatens fair trial: Thomas lawyer"] ''The Age,'' 12 January 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> yet weeks later would defend McLennan publicly against the [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]] police.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/defiant-artist-flies-his-unaustralian-flag-again/2006/02/28/1141095741391.html "Defiant artist flies his 'UnAustralian' flag again"] ''The Age,'' 1 March 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref>
=== Trocadero Art Space === Only weeks after the ''Pay Your Way'' affair, McLennan's ''Proudly UnAustralian'' was removed by the [[Victoria Police]] in Melbourne. The exhibition – featuring a burnt Australian flag – took place at Trocadero Art Space who rents a public billboard to exhibiting artists. It was to coincide with the 2006 [[Australia Day]] in January. The work was removed some days prior this date and McLennan arrived back in Australia days later to a media furore. The scandal had been criticised as offensive by those such as Federal [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] MP [[Bronwyn Bishop]] who attempted to introduce a ban on [[Flag desecration|flag burning]], and the national president of the [[Returned and Services League of Australia|Returned and Services League]]. [[Free speech]] advocates such as the [[National Association for the Visual Arts]] and criminal defence lawyer Rob Stary denounced the police's actions as an attack on [[civil rights]]. This took place only a few short months after the [[2005 Cronulla riots]] and fuelled the broader debate about [[racism in Australia]].<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2006/s1563582.htm "Art prompts call for flag-burning law change"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060211040610/http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2006/s1563582.htm |date=11 February 2006 }} ''The 7.30 Report'' (Transcript), 6 February 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Australian Centre for Contemporary Art === McLennan wrote an article in 2006 criticising the Artistic Director of the [[Australian Centre for Contemporary Art]] (ACCA), Juliana Engberg over her reaction to artist and VCA student, Ash Keating and his appropriation of ACCA's waste disposal for the use of his art. The Engberg/Keating scandal became widely known amongst Melbourne art circles from the ACCA exhibition opening where it took place and later through the independent electronic magazine [[Crikey]]. McLennan's polemic further fuelled debate over Engberg's credentials.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/power-of-one/2006/08/31/1156817027357.html "Power of one"] ''The Age,'' 1 September 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Anna Schwartz Gallery === McLennan featured in ''Rules of Engagement'' at Melbourne ARI West Space in May 2007, which dealt with "relationships, power and exchange within the art system" according to the show's curator Mark Feary.<ref>[http://www.westspace.org.au/projects/rules-of-engagement.html?Itemid=0 "Rules of Engagement"] ''West Space'' (Catalogue Essay), May 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> McLennan's contribution, ''Art in a Capitalist Society'' depicted an authoritative picture of leading private Australian gallerist Anna Schwartz, linked to a quote about [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]] from the [[Karl Marx]] treatise ''[[Das Kapital]]''. Schwartz has previously criticised McLennan<ref name="The politics" /> and some have accused McLennan of taking revenge.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/artists-dish-it-out-to-the-dealers/2007/06/14/1181414455138.html "Artists dish it out to the dealers"] ''The Age,'' 15 June 2007. Accessed 25 April 2008</ref>
=== University of Melbourne === In a July 2009, ''[[Farrago (newspaper)|Farrago]]'' interview, McLennan attacked the [[University of Melbourne]] over the merger with the [[Victorian College of the Arts]], the [[Melbourne Model]], the liquidation of the [[Victorian College of the Arts Student Union|VCA Student Union]] and likened the Vice-chancellor, [[Glyn Davis]]' perceived political censorship to [[Adolf Hitler]]'s use of [[Nazi art|Fascist Art]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]'s use of [[Socialist Realism]]. He also depicted Davis and the Provost, [[Peter McPhee (academic)|Peter McPhee]], as [[Sex Pistols]] musicians, [[Johnny Rotten]] and [[Sid Vicious]] in a parody of the [[Sex Pistols#Never Mind the Bollocks|Never Mind the Bollocks]] album cover as well as depicting Davis as the violent [[psychopath]], [[Alex DeLarge]] in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s film adaptation of [[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]].<ref>"Report on the death of the VCA" ''Farrago,'' Edition 5, July 2009, p. 28–29.</ref> McLennan had previously attacked Davis and the university administration as the former General Secretary of the VCA Student Union.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1659&Itemid=106 Smashing jobs, courses and student unions: A 2020 vision?] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 128, May 2008. Accessed 28 July 2009</ref>

{{Infobox geographical indication | name = Bastar Wooden Craft | color = Blue | logo = | image = 022a-bastar ladies all togather.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | alternative names = | description = <!-- Describe in brief --> | type = Handicraft | area = [[Bastar district]], [[Chhattisgarh]] | country = India | registered = 2008–2009 | material = Wood | official website = <!-- {{URL|wwww.example.org}} --> }} '''Bastar Wooden Crafts''' are traditional Indian [[wood]]en crafts that are manufactured in the [[Bastar district|Bastar]] district of [[Chhattisgarh]] state, [[India]]. The wood-crafting work has been protected under the [[Geographical indication]] (GI) of the [[Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights]] (TRIPS) agreement. It is listed at item 84 as "Bastar Wooden Craft" of the GI Act 1999 of the Government of India with registration confirmed by the Controller General of Patents Designs and Trademarks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ipindia.nic.in/girindia/treasures_protected/registered_GI_18November2015.pdf|title=State Wise Registration Details Of G.I Applications|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=Controller General of Patents Designs and Trademarks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201065403/http://ipindia.nic.in/girindia/treasures_protected/registered_GI_18November2015.pdf|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=}}</ref>
Generally people in Chhattisgarh, especially Bastar people have excellent skills in variety of craft work including [[Dhokra]], bamboo craft, wrought iron craft, tribal dress, traditional textile, Kantha embroidery, [[terracotta]], tribal painting, [[bell metal]], etc. Their skills have been recognized by national and state awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cghandicraft.com/state-award.aspx |title=AWARD LIST |publisher=Chhattisgarh Handicrafts Development Board |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206232302/http://www.cghandicraft.com/state-award.aspx |archivedate=6 February 2016 |df= }}</ref> [[Badhai]] people are skilled in this woodcraft work and they are divided into two groups. One group make agricultural instruments and other group make decorative and totemic pillars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cghandicraft.com/wood-craft.asp |title=Wood Craft |publisher=Chhattisgarh Handicrafts Development Board |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913013104/http://www.cghandicraft.com/wood-craft.asp |archivedate=13 September 2015 |df= }}</ref> Another community, knows as [[Muria people]] also has woodcarving skills. The Murias are best in craftsmanship. Their skill apply in various objects that from small to big.<ref>{{cite book | title=History, Religion and Culture of India, Volume 5 | publisher=Gyan Publishing House | author=Gajrani, S. | pages=310 | isbn=8182050642}}</ref> They turn craft skills into interpretation of basic lifestyles and basic routines of life such as [[threshing|chaffing]] of paddy, [[Grinding (abrasive cutting)|grinding]] grains, etc. They express their culture and religious faiths into craft art that reflect through gods, goddess, music culture of the community and wildlife. The craft work heavily depended as hand-made where there is no machinery usage or rare use in particular areas only.
Woodcraft in Bastar has beautiful and unique form of art that was mastered by Bastar tribal and it helps their livelihood. The handicrafts product has decent market in different parts of India as well as in some foreign countries. They use [[teak]] wood, [[Dalbergia sissoo|Indian Rosewood]], whitewood and other finest wood to craft various handicraft items.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.indiatourismecatalog.com/india_tribal_rural/tribal_rural_chhattisgarh.html | title=Handicraft in Chhattisgarh | accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> Bastar Wooden Craft has been exhibited at "Durbar Hall Art Gallery" too.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/true-tribal-mettle/article1417089.ece | title=True tribal mettle | publisher=The Hindu | date=22 May 2008 | accessdate=7 February 2016}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Chocolate box}} [[File:Wrayland Manor - geograph.org.uk - 437386.jpg|200px|thumb|Wrayland Manor. The [[archetypal]] chocolate box [[Devon]] thatched house in the [[hamlet (place)|hamlet]] of Wrayland. Several old chocolate boxes and postcards depict this particular building, calling it variously the Hall House and an "Old [[Cottage]]".]] '''Chocolate box art''' originally referred literally to [[Decorative arts|decorations]] on [[chocolate]] boxes. Over the years, however, the terminology has changed; it is now applied broadly as an often pejorative term to describe [[painting]]s and [[design]]s that are overly idealistic and sentimental.
Using his own paintings of children, flowers and holiday scenes [[Richard Cadbury]], the son of the founder of [[Cadbury plc|Cadbury's]], introduced such designs to his chocolate boxes in the late 19th century.<ref>[http://www.cadbury.co.uk/cadburyandchocolate/ourstory/packaging/Pages/richardcadbury.aspx "Cadbury chocolate box"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520074709/http://www.cadbury.co.uk/cadburyandchocolate/ourstory/packaging/Pages/richardcadbury.aspx |date=2009-05-20 }}. [[Cadbury]].</ref>
[[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]]'s paintings have been described as "chocolate box" and have been derided by [[Edgar Degas|Degas]] and [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]] for being happy, inoffensive scenes.<ref>Jones, Jonathan (12 February 2007). [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2007/feb/12/art.features11 "Angry young man"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref> [[John Constable|Constable]]'s landscapes have also been so described.<ref>[http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/culturevulture/archives/2006/05/25/lanscapes_of_gl.html "Landscapes of gloom"]. ''The Guardian''. 25 May 2006 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615031837/http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/culturevulture/archives/2006/05/25/lanscapes_of_gl.html |date=15 June 2006 }}</ref>
[[Aelbert Cuyp]]'s ''[[Media:Aelbert Cuyp River Landscape.jpg|River Landscape]]'' (1660), despite being widely regarded as his best work, has been criticised as having "chocolate box blandness".<ref>Denny, Ned (18 March 2002). [http://www.newstatesman.com/200203180037 "Cuyp cake"]. ''[[New Statesman]]''.</ref> [[Fred Swan]] is a modern-day proponent of chocolate box paintings as, to his detractors, was [[Thomas Kinkade]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/kinkade-king-of-kitsch-coming-to--a-home-near-you-683724.html| title=Kinkade, king of kitsch, coming to a home near you |newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=5 May 2001| accessdate=8 May 2009| location=London |first=Cahal| last=Milmo}}</ref>
The term has also been applied to [[sculpture]]. A young couple standing locked in an embrace forms the centrepiece for the new £800m [[St Pancras railway station|St Pancras International]] station in [[central London]]. Entitled ''The Meeting Place'', the £1m sculpture is by [[British people|Briton]] [[Paul Day (sculptor)|Paul Day]] who admitted, "Some will say it is a chocolate box sculpture".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/art-that-embraces-a-new-future-for-st-pancras-436300.html |title=Art that embraces a new future for St Pancras |first=Cahal |last=Milmo |newspaper=The Independent|date=14 February 2007 |accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Color symbolism''' in [[art]] and [[anthropology]] refers to the use of color as a [[symbol]] in various [[Culture|cultures]]. There is great diversity in the use of colors and their associations between cultures<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Smith|first=N.S. |last2=Whitfield|first2=T.W.A. |last3=Wiltshire|first3=T.J. |date=April 1990 |title=The accuracy of the NCS, DIN, and OSA-UCS colour atlases |journal=Color Research & Application |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=111–116 |doi=10.1002/col.5080150209 |issn=0361-2317}}</ref> and even within the same culture in different time periods.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Color psychology and color therapy: a factual study of the influence of color on human life |last=Birren |first=Faber |date=2006 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=978-1425424107 |location=Whitefish, MT |oclc=74452551}}</ref> The same color may have very different associations within the same culture at any time. Diversity in color symbolism occurs because color meanings and symbolism occur on an individual, cultural and universal basis. Color symbolism is also context-dependent and influenced by changes over time.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Color symbolism |doi=10.5040/9781501303364.ch-014 |title=Color Studies |editor1=Edith Anderson Feisner |editor2=Ronald Reed |edition=3rd |year=2016 |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=New York |isbn=978-1-50130-336-4 |oclc=1053938255 }}</ref> Symbolic representations of religious concepts or articles may include a specific color with which the concept or object is associated.<ref>{{Cite journal |language=de |title=Encyclopaedia Britannica|doi=10.1163/9789004337862_lgbo_com_050367 }}</ref> There is evidence to suggest that colors have been used for this purpose as early as 90,000 BC.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
== Common associations ==
=== Red === Red is often associated with love, passion, and lust. It is frequently used in relation to Valentine's Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=valentine&safe=off&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJobTilr7eAhWCLn0KHaP-BZIQ_AUIFCgC&biw=1366&bih=618 |title=valentine - Google Search|website=www.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It can also be used to signify danger or warning. For instance, it is used for stop signs<ref>{{Citation|title=Road vertical signs. Variable message traffic signs|publisher=BSI British Standards|doi=10.3403/03263875u}}</ref> and fire engines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocklandfirefighters.org/?zone=/unionactive/view_article.cfm&HomeID=50076&page=Fire20Department20Traditions|title=Why are fire trucks red?|website=www.rocklandfirefighters.org|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> In China, red is often used to symbolize good luck or happiness, and is used for many holidays or weddings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/color-symbolism-in-chinese-culture-what-do-traditional-chinese-colors-mean/|title=Color Symbolism in Chinese Culture: What do Traditional Chinese Colors Mean?|date=2015-01-16|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Blue === Blue is the color of the ocean and the sky; it often symbolizes serenity, stability, or inspiration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-blue/|title=Meaning of The Color Blue {{!}}|last=|first=|date=2011-01-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> It can be a calming color, and symbolize reliability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/blue-color-meaning-the-color-blue/|title=Blue Color Meaning - The Color Blue|last=|first=|date=2013-03-01|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> In the Catholic Church, the Virgin Mary is most often depicted wearing blue, to symbolize her divinity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aleteia.org/2017/06/24/why-is-the-blessed-virgin-mary-always-wearing-blue/|title=Why is the Blessed Virgin Mary always wearing blue?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-24|work=Aleteia — Catholic Spirituality, Lifestyle, World News, and Culture|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Blue is widely used for baby boys' clothes or bedrooms, although the reason blue is so strongly associated with boys is debated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/22037-pink-girls-blue-boys.html|title=Why Is Pink for Girls and Blue for Boys?|date=1 August 2012|first=Natalie|last=Wolchover|work=Live Science|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Yellow === Yellow is a color often associated with sunshine or joy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colormatters.com/the-meanings-of-colors/yellow|title=Yellow|last=Morton|first=Jill|website=www.colormatters.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It is sometimes used in association with cowardice or fear, i.e, the phrase "yellow-bellied".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/yellow-bellied|title=yellow-bellied - Dictionary Definition|work=Vocabulary.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Children tend to like this color, and it is used to market products to children;<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-yellow/|title=Meaning of The Color Yellow {{!}}|date=2011-02-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> it is also used for school buses and taxi cabs since it is such a bright, noticeable color.<ref name=":0" />
=== Green === Green is most often used to represent nature, healing, or fertility, since it's such a dominant color in nature. It can be a very relaxing color<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-green/|title=Meaning of The Color Green {{!}}|date=2011-01-25|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> but is also used in the US to symbolize money, greed, or jealousy.<ref name=":1" /> Saying that someone is "green" means they're inexperienced or new.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/green|title=Green definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
=== Black === Black, in Western culture, is considered a negative color and usually symbolizes death, grief, or evil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorpsychology.org/black/|title=Black Color Psychology - Black Meaning & Personality|work=Color Psychology|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> People often wear black for mourning, although this practice isn't as wide-spread as it was in the past.<ref>{{Citation|last=Jalland|first=Pat|date=1996-11-07|pages=77–97|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198201885|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198201885.003.0005|title=Death in the Victorian Family|chapter=Death and the Victorian Doctors}}</ref>
=== White === White most often symbolizes perfection, faith, innocence, softness, and cleanliness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-white/|title=Meaning of The Color White {{!}}|date=2010-12-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Brides often wear white dresses to symbolize virginity or purity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridesmagazine.co.uk/article/why-do-brides-wear-white|title=Why Do Brides Wear White? And Other Questions|last=Davis|first=Lexxi|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
=== Pink === Pink is associated with softness, femininity, sweetness, and love.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-pink/|title=Meaning of The Color Pink {{!}}|date=2010-11-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> However, it was formerly used as a masculine color, frequently used for baby boys; it wasn't until the early 20th century that the gender roles of pink and blue were reversed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/health/colorscope-pink-boy-girl-gender/index.html|title=The complicated gender history of pink|last=Ant|first=Puja Bhattacharjee, CNN Animation by Giant|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
==Color symbolism in marketing== Color plays an important role in setting expectations for a product and communicating its key characteristics.<ref name=Asiam>{{Cite journal |last=Aslam |first=Mubeen M. |date=2006 |title=Are You Selling the Right Colour? A Cross‐Cultural Review of Colour as a Marketing Cue |journal=Journal of Marketing Communications |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=15–30 |doi=10.1080/13527260500247827}}</ref> Color is the second most important element that allows consumers to identify brand packaging.<ref name=Popa>{{Cite journal|last=Popa|first=C.N. |last2=Popescu|first2=S. |last3=Berehoiu|first3=R.M.T. |last4=Berehoiu|first4=S.M.T. |date=2013 |title=Considerations regarding use and role of colour in marketing |url=http://managementjournal.usamv.ro/pdf/vol.XIII/Art44.pdf |journal= Scientific Papers Series - Management, Economic Engineering in Agriculture and Rural Development |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=269–274}}</ref>
Marketers for products with an international market navigate the color symbolism variances between cultures with targeted advertising. The car manufacturer, Volkswagen ran a commercial in Italy with a black sheep in the middle of a larger flock symbolizing those who owned a VW Golf as someone unique and self-assured among a crowd of others who were not. In several cultures around the world, a black sheep represents an outcast and is seen as something undesirable. In Italy, a black sheep represents confidence and independence.[[File:Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017.jpg|thumb|Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017]] There are many additional variances in color symbolism between cultures. Cold is symbolized by blue in East Asia, the USA, and Sweden while warmth is symbolized by yellow in the USA and by blue in The Netherlands. Sometimes the meanings of colors are in stark opposition across geographic boundaries, requiring products marketed to specific demographics to account for those changes across different markets. For instance, feminity is symbolized by blue in The Netherlands and pink in the USA., whereas masculinity is symbolized by blue in Sweden and the USA, and red in the UK and France.<ref name=Asiam/> In some instances color symbolism in marketing is constructed. For companies whose products are defined by the name of their color their sales are susceptible to the symbolism and association of that name. In one example, a company selling a paint color named “off white” more than doubled its sales by renaming the same color as “ancient silk.”<ref name=Popa/>
==Conceptualizations of colors cross-culturally== Color symbolism has morphed over time. Between the 5th and 17th centuries color was largely related to in a religious context. Blue was symbolic of heaven and white of purity. Today, purity is still symbolized by white in Australia and the USA but by blue in other countries like India. Similarly, the church influenced the perception of colors like crimson and purple. Largely because the dyes for these colors could only be sourced from precious pigments, religious figures like Madonna, Cardinals, and the Virgin were seen in scarlet and purple. [[File:Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart.JPG|thumb|Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart]]Today, purple symbolizes evil and infidelity in Japan, but the same is symbolized by blue in East Asia and by yellow in France. Additionally, the sacred color of Hindu and Buddhist monks is orange. [[File:Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap.jpg|thumb|Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap]] The Renaissance was also a time in which black and purple were colors of mourning. Today, Mourning or death is symbolized by white in East Asia, black in the USA, and blue in Iran, while happiness is symbolized by white in Australia and NZ, and yellow in China.<ref name=Asiam/>
There is a general disagreement over whether reactions to color and their symbolism are a result of cultural conditioning or of instinct. Several studies concluded that color is part of the social learning process because of the significant symbolism within the culture. High quality, trustworthiness and dependability are symbolized by blue in the USA, Japan, Korea and green and yellow in China - as well as purple in China, South Korea and Japan. Because of these variances, critical cues vary across cultures. Warning signs are coded differently as danger is symbolized by green in Malaysia, and red in the USA and Mexico. The same color of green symbolizes envy in Belgium and the USA, but envy is symbolized by yellow in Germany and Russia, and purple in Mexico. Even the colors that denote powerful emotions vary. Love is symbolized by green in Japan, red and purple in China, Korea, Japan and the USA. Unluckiness is symbolized by red in Chad, Nigeria and Germany. Luckiness is symbolized by red in China, Denmark and Argentina. The traditional bridal color is red in China and white in the USA. Ambition and desire are symbolized by red in India.<ref name=Asiam/>
== Color symbolism in Arabic culture == Color has different meanings in different countries. We can specifically look at the Arabic culture and take it into consideration. We can start with the color white. In the Arabic culture, white is thought of as the color that is symbolic for nature. Since it related with nature, it has a meaning that is one of positivity. It also relates with that of being clean and pure. White is a color that is commonly worn during prayers and with that, it symbolizes purity. White’s positive connotation carries out into other aspects. It is also used as a symbol for positivity in the future. White is also used to symbolize the end of war. You will also see women adorn white at their weddings as a sign of positivity. Since doves are white, they share the symbolic meaning that comes with the color. This in turn causes them to be associated with positivity of good news.
When you look at the color Black in Arabic culture you can find that it is related to funerals and death. Women will often wear black to funerals in order to show that they are sad for those who have passed. Also relating to death, black is associated with hell. Black is also used to symbolize dark. Hell is thought to be a dark black place associating black as negative. Black in general is looked at as having negative connotations around it. For example, the symbolism of a black heart refers to someone who is unkind. [[File:Red rose with black background.jpg|thumb]] Green is a color that is commonly found in Islam. It is a color found in nature and with this, it is associated with and represents goodness. Green is a color that has an overall positive meaning. The color green also has to do with truthfulness, again going with positivity. If you look at phrases, the symbolic meanings are generally positive. If you look at the phrase green hand, it relates to being generous which is a positive thing.
Red has an overall positive association with it. Often you will find that red is a color associated with roses and blood. The color red has to do with love and passion. In sayings you can find it to have either a negative or positive meaning such as the term red eye relates with anger. The Arabic culture also associates this color with death.
Blue is related with positivity when discussing it with nature, otherwise it can be related with negative connotations. When used in the phrase blue eyes, it refers to jealousy. A blue body relates with death and therefore is associated with negativity.
Yellow is another color that is also associated with nature and the sun. Again, since it is a color related with nature, it takes on the symbolic meaning of positivity. Gold is also categorized under here and is also takes on a positive meaning. Generally, when used in phrases, the color yellow has to do with negativity. For example, a yellow smile means to be mean.
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasan|first=Amna|date=2011|title=How Colours are Semantically Construed in the Arabic and English Culture: A Comparative study|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1080712.pdf|journal=English Language Teaching|volume=4|pages=206–213|via=}}</ref> ==Colors and emotions== [[File:Emotions - 3.png|thumb]] Color symbolism is displayed in many ways. One of the most common ways we see color symbolism displayed in through our emotions. In this article Color-emotions associations: Past experience and personal preference it takes a look at how we connect colors with our emotions and how it depends on a person’s preference and or their past experiences. This article first starts out by talking about the different colors and what they are associated with. The first color it talks about is the color blue and how people see blue as comfort and security and how they see orange as being upsetting. The next one they talk about is yellow which is more of a happy color compared to purple which they say is dignified but I have never heard of purple being seen that way. The next one this article talks about which I find very interesting is the color red. People view the color red in two different ways, one being as a strong and passionate color. However, it is also seen in a very different way, people see it as an aggressive color because it is the color of blood. The last color this article talks about is the color green and how just like red it has two different views. Green can be viewed positively as in quietness but can also be viewed negatively as in guilt. This study took a look at how we associate colors with emotions. This study was done and showed that we associated lighter colors such as blue or yellow with more positive emotions. It then showed how we associated darker colors such as grey or black with more native emotions. However, something very interesting that this study did find is that most young prefer the color black over many other colors. The study was done with college aged students to see how they associate their emotions with colors. Many tests were done such as matching tasks and matching color tests to see what colors they associate with their emotions. The study had 44 men and 54 women in it and they again were all college students. They identified a color sample with one emotion only and it showed what emotional response is connected to a color. The results from this study did find that people mostly associate the color green with being the most positive. Over 95% off people said that green s the most positive because it makes them feel relaxed and then comfortable and at peace. It also showed that people saw yellow as the more excited and energetic emotion, with over 90% agreeing with this. 79% of students found that blue was a calming color because it reminded them of the ocean which is known as a calming place. People did have different answers when it came to red because like explained earlier, red is seen in two very different ways, It has been seen as love by many but also as evil because it remind people of blood. Many people did not seem to like the color purple very much as it was not favored by many for their preferences. The color black was seen to be more negative emotions like fear and depression. Overall, this article shows how color can be important because it is how people associate their emotions and things based on color symbolism.<ref>Kaya & H., Naz & Helen. Color-emotion association: Past experience and personal preference. The University of Georgia, Department of Textiles, Merchandising, and Interiors, 2004.</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://books.google.com/?id=lCoAb9RDVIYC&pg=PA31&dq=color+symbolism+#v=onepage&q=color%20symbolism&f=false | title=AIC 2004 Color and Paints, Interim Meeting of the International Color Association, Proceedings}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=August 2007}} {{Architecturalelement-stub}} [[image:sch_ewf_6.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Example of a color wash in multiple hues]] A '''color wash''' is a popular technique in [[faux painting]] using [[paint]] thinned out with [[glaze (painting technique)|glaze]] to create a subtle wash of color over walls or other surfaces.
Color washing is an easy and forgiving form of faux finishing often used by beginners, but perfected by professional finishers. It was historically created with oil-based products because of the long drying time, but today's environmental and health conscious companies are producing user-friendly water based glazes. Color washing can be done in any color of paint and is generally applied with brushes over a solid paint color, using long sweeping strokes to meld the glaze colors together.
[[Category:Faux painting]] [[Category:Decorative arts]] [[Category:Artistic techniques]]

{{use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{for|the Italian road bicycle racer|Salvatore Commesso}} '''Commesso also known as Florentine Commesso''', also referred to as '''Florentine mosaic''', is a method of piecing together cut sections of luminous, narrow [[gemstones]] to form works of art.''[[Encyclopædia Britannica#1994–present|Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' (1998). Art – [https://www.britannica.com/art/commesso "Commesso"]. [[Encyclopaedia Britannica, inc.]] Accessed March 03, 2017. Precise patterns are cut into a slab of (generally black) [[marble]]. Gems are then cautiously cut and meticulously inlaid into these patterns. The work is then [[Polishing|polished]] section by section, as it cannot be polished as a whole due to gems having different hardnesses.{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia=[[Cyclopaedia of Useful Arts: Mechanical and Chemical, Manufactures, Mining and Engineering|Cyclopaedia of Useful Arts: Mechanical and Chemical, Manufactures, Mining and Engineering]] | title=Mosaic | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZU9AQAAMAAJ | editor=Tomlinson, Charles | publisher=[[J. S. Virtue]] | location=London and New York | year=1862 | volume=2; Hammer to Zirconium. | at=pp. 304–305; Florentine mosaic}} The assembly between each pieces is made using glue made with a mixture of virgin wax and colophony. The Master personally follow the whole creative process and all mosaics are completely produced in the laboratory The practice, which began in [[Florence, Italy|Florence]], Italy, dates back to at least the 14th century and gained prominence just before the 17th century. Some of its uses include making pictures and decorating furniture and architecture. '''It is know all over the world for its excellence and old tradition and it is still alive today and kept alive from Tuscany masters, with the magnificent and magical atmosphere in their ancient “botteghe”.''' '''"Commesso is something you will love and admire each day for a life, something that is perfect now and will be perfect forever because stones never change"'''{{Cite web|url=https://www.commessofiorentino.com|title=CommessoFiorentino.com|last=Guido|first=Bedarida|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Image gallery== {| border="0" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="4" style="margin:auto; border:2px solid #9d9d9d; background:#eee;" |- |
